subject_label: Manuscripts, Arabic;New Jersey--Princeton
physical_description: Extent: 375 p. (8-12 lines), bound ; 36 cm.
note: Page 1 of flyleaf bears Scheide bookplate.|Illuminated ms. in naskh script on glazed oriental paper. 35.6 x 23.5 cm. Titles of first two sūrahs in white; titles of the other 112 sūrahs in gold. Text and vocalization in black ink; recitation notes in red ink. Text is fully vocalized. Verses terminate in gold discs. Groups of ten verses indicated by the word ʻashr (ten) in the margin. Gilt medallions in the margins also contain textual divisions. Text area of folios 1b and 2a surrounded by elaborate decoration bound by a ruled gold and blue frame. Two cartouches on either side of the text. Titles on gold background at top and bottom with blue background. Taken together, the two facing leaves form three intersecting mandorlas: two vertical, one horizontal. A floral motif is superimposed overall. Margins consist of sets of blue parallel lines with stylized floral motifs along them. Subsequent text areas bordered by a ruled frame of gilt and blue. Subsequent titles in gold in a rectangular frame with blue and red floral background.|Paper is glazed oriental stock, handmade. Lower margins of f. 1 and 266 have paper repairs, but text is not affected. Minor repairs to edges of several other leaves. Some minor stains and soiling. Slight water damage to upper margins of last 12 folios.|Binding is brown leather. Spine has title stamped in gold, triple fillets at head and foot. Borders of covers have two gold stamped triple fillets separated by a gold stamped scroll design. Inside corners have incised scallop design inlaid with gilt leather showing vine motif in red in relief. Cover centers have incised mandorlas with tulips at top and bottom in same fashion. Doublures are leather with gold stamped double fillets separated by gold stamped scroll border. At center is gold stamped mandorla.|M 120. Acquired in 1938 from A.W.S. Rosenbach. Collection of John H. Scheide.

Bulliet, "Medieval Arabic Tarsh: A Forgotten Chapter in the History of Printing," Journal of the American Oriental Society 107 (1987), 427-438.|WHS fragment acquired at auction (Sotheby's, London, Oriental Manuscripts, 22 October 1993, lot no. 25) by William H. Scheide through Christopher Edwards.

physical_description: Extent: 302 p. (15 lines), bound ; 17 cm.
note: Caption title.|Text begins on f. 2b.|Leaf 1b bears table of contents.|Page 2 of cover bears Scheide bookplate and notation: Scheide M 123-3.1.10.|Ms. in naskh script on glazed paper. 16.8 x 11.4 cm. Text area framed in ruled lines of gold or red ink. Poetry text arranged in two columns, separated by ruled lines. Headings, keywords, overlinings and some punctuation in red ink. Some vocalization. Catchwords; some marginalia.|Paper is glazed laid stock. Some leaves slightly discolored; stitching in first signature broken. Some leaves bear partial watermark showing a crown and part of a crest. Some smudging and ink smears.|Binding is leather over boards, wallet style. Spine plain; covers have gilt stamped fillets and scroll design at borders. Centers have gilt stamped mandorlas with floral design in relief. Mandorlas flanked at top and bottom by gilt stamped rosettes. Fore edge flap has single fillet frame and three gilt rosettes. Envelope flap has gilt stamped fillets and scroll band with gilt rosettes at outer corners. Gilt stamped mandorla at center with floral motif in relief. Fore edge flap damaged at foot.|Scheide M 123. Purchased by John Hinsdale Scheide as part of lot 255, Ormand G. Smith/George E. Chisholm sale, Parke-Bernet Galleries, New York, November 9, 1938.

Remnants of earlier foliation.|Provenance: The names of mayors and other officials of the city of Lincoln, from 32 Edw. I to the end of the 15th century, are written throughout the manuscript; it was probably in the possession of the Corporation until the beginning of the 17th century; in 1724 it was given to William Pownall of Lincoln, who disposed of it to Sir Richard Ellys of Nocton, Lincolnshire; passed by inheritance to the Marquess of Lothian, Blickling Hall, Norfolk; his sale (Jan. 27, 1932, no. 2, facs.) to Cortland F. Bishop; acquired at Bishop sale, New York, 5 April 1938, lot 285.

note: Ms. codex.|Decoration: Tail-piece with simple calligraphic ornament; rubrics, and marks to indicate textual divisions.|Origin: Written, according the the colophon on the last leaf, at the monastery of Mar Joseph at Arvana near Balad (now Eski Mosul) Iraq, on Monday the 25th of the Second Teshrin in the year 1533 of Alexander, and the year 618 of the Arabs (i.e. A.D. 1221).|Early owner, the priest of Hasan, son of Adb al-Masih, who bought it for 5 dinars; presented to Athelstan Riley, Commissioner of the Archbishop of Canterbury to the East in 1884, by Mar Shimou, Patriarch of the East at his village of Kochanes; exhibited, 1889, at an Ecclesiastical Art Exhibition (no. 378) held at Portman Rooms by the Church of England Working Men's Society; obtained from Maggs (Cat. 871, no. 77, 1960), Oct. 4, 1960.

subject_label: Manuscripts, Greek;New Jersey--Princeton
physical_description: Extent: 268 leaves : parchment ; 122 x 100 (120 x 45) mm.
note: Ms. codex.|Cataloged from existing description.|Layout: 22 lines per page; framed ruled in dry point.|Collation: 1⁶, 2-10⁸, 11⁴, 12-34⁸, 35².|Decoration: full-page miniatures; canon tables with decorative frames, marginal figures, and ornament; 2 Eusebian letter pages with historiated frames with marginal figures; initials and headpieces for each Gospel.|Probably 16th c. Dark-red goatskin over poplar boards with unsupported link stitch.|Early provenance unknown. Probably in the library of St. John of Prodromos (see library shelfmark no. gamma 14 on the inside front board), as the property of the monk Makarios. It was probably rebound in the monastery, like many other manuscripts, and remained there until 1917, when it was removed together with most of the manuscripts in the library.
